title: Funny Signs
content:
I see quite a few wooden signs with the letters turned all which ways and mixed up fonts. Here's one that I pass every day:   
   
 ![corona ranch](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/35412.jpg)   
   
Anyone else catch some of these in the wild?
author: mica

comments.content: Must be a deadNd street :-)

I started taking photos of inverted and flipped letters a few years ago, but gave up when I realised just how often this happens. My favourite example is in Brompton Oratory in London: there is a monumental text running around the inside of the dome in brass letters that must be at least 3ft high (it is difficult to judge, because it is so far up). One of the Xs is upside down.

Sign in Rome.   
 [http://socialdesignzine.aiapnet.it/images/cartello.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/socialdesignzine.aiapnet.it/images/cartello.jpg)   
"For turists: no parking here please.   
For everybody else: you pissed me off.   
Sunday open."   
   
NoWindows   
 [http://homepage.mac.com/juggle5/fun/NoWindows.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/homepage.mac.com/juggle5/fun/NoWindows.jpg)

would you eat here?   
 ![asian restaurant](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/35524.jpg)

Ole, there's an oriental restaurant in Glendale called "My Dung".   
And it recently closed because of a rat problem. No joke.   
   
hhp

In Blackpool i saw a Chinese restaurant called 'Junk'. It was closed.   
Ahhh, Blackpool.   
   
Where I live, we have a candy called 'Spunk'.   
It's liqourice in case you're wondering, but then again, we use English names for all our Oriental restaurants...

Ole ... I love it! ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
What a fantastic name, must be a popular place!   
   
R
Not as popular as the "Pu Ping" restaurant
![MEGAFLICKS](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/35592.jpg)

Alessandro,   
It looks like it is your kern to be funny :-)
![biciclette](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/35837.jpg)

LOL!!! Looks like some serious over-kerning in photos 3 and 4   
:-)

More bicycle lane fun:   
   
 [http://www.geocities.com/fredpipes/cyclelanes/cyclelane4.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/www.geocities.com/fredpipes/cyclelanes/cyclelane4.html)   
   
Link via [This Is Broken](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/broken.typepad.com/). You can usually find some great oddball signs and completely distressing instructions over there. This is one of my favorites:   
   
 [http://www.goodexperience.com/broken/i/04/04/union\_station-s.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/www.goodexperience.com/broken/i/04/04/union_station-s.jpg)

AH AH!   
Thanks for the link, this is my favorite:   
 [http://www.goodexperience.com/broken/i/03/11/whichway.s.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600/http:/www.goodexperience.com/broken/i/03/11/whichway.s.jpg)   
 ![FL cannot proceed](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/36022.gif)

I've been driving past the sign at the top of this thread for over four years now, and they \_just\_ changed it:   
   
 ![new ranch](http://web.archive.org/web/20110102144600im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/37280.jpg)
maybe someone alerted them to yer earlier post. ;^)

\>turned all which ways and mixed up fonts   
   
Ah, the power of professional desktop typography. No longer do we have to suffer quaint amateurism, now that we have horizontal scaling!

Nick,   
\>now that we have horizontal scaling!\<   
   
I always felt that Tennis was a better sport than SQUASH :-)

There was a maltt shop just of I-94 in St. Paul with a sign-board with movable letters. For the longest time it read:   
   
"Children Eat Free Balloons On Tuesday!"   
   
Such a deal!

Not in print, but Kristin's sign reminds me of the radio ad from my hometown that ran when I was a kid: (about sandwiches)   
   
"If they're too big for the kids, ask us to cut them in half."   
   
Antecedents, anyone?
I got an old card in my wallet from a restaurant in Turkey, on the back they wrote: 'Bring this card and get 10% discount, free fruit, free ice cream, free irish caf
